answers.author: Harry Kenworthy
answers.text:
I recently did a webinar for ICMA on January 19, 2011 on Metrics which we view as Measure What Matters (we have a "top 5" focus mentality) and 68 cities were in attendance.  The fundamental problem you raise is you don't have top management commitment and/or even understanding the value of what you're doing.  My suggestions would be as follows:
1. Provide more info and education to the top management team along with providing them links to other City sites already using metrics - this starts to develop knowledge.
2. Provide them the case (elevator speech) of What are we doing, Why are we doing it, What do you expect out of them, and What's in it for them.  It's all about realizing that this has a direct benefit to top management.
3. If top management doesn't know and doesn't want to know, then you're working to develop metrics that your peers realize are valuable to them for the same reasons (elevator speech).  It's always best for the Mayor or City Manager to clearly set expectations for metrics and then seriously follow through to make sure it happens.
If you find yourself in a situation where you're dong the right things, without management "getting it" and your ability to keep your peers engaged in the value of metrics is slumping, it makes no sense to whine about it, just decide if you want to continue to be in this environment or move on to a better situation with better management.
We always find that Leadership is the key.  Good leadership causes great things to happen.  See a recent attached article.  hwk455@comcast.net

answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
find areas of support and work there . . . if the measures are not used by higher ups, ask yourself if you are measuring things that are important to them, or that can help guide their decision making . . . if you have support at the work group level in departments, make sure the measures you are helping them select are ones they need as managers to manage the business -- that will help the data get collected, analyzed and used . . . really, go find the pockets where support still exists and help them get better through the use of their data -- others will notice and want the same thing.

answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
It's hard to be specific with knowing something about the agency or government characteristics or your performance measures. That said, here are some general thoughts.
Link to Outcomes: PM's should be linked to clear  outcomes, usually drawn from a mission document or strategic plan that managers and/or electeds have helped develop. Then PM's measure progress towards results that folks care about.
Sets: There is no one perfect KPI. We use clusters, or sets, of PM's around each outcome to create a more nuanced and balanced perspective.
Relevance: Annual performance reports are necessary for continuity and transparency, but usually most interesting to the analyst types. It's hard for managers and electeds to relate these to the burning issues of their day. Weave relevant PM's into the analysis of current topics. Make the PM's relevant to the issues that decision makers are facing. For example, we report on the cost recovery rate of recreation programs. Mildly interesting by itself. But when faced with budget cuts, we included cost recovery performance in the budget program analysis of cut options, both in issue papers and presentations to the budget advisory committee. Then this performance measure became exceedingly relevant. Make the PM's work hard.

answers.author: Gerald Young
answers.text:
Outcomes are certainly a key consideration.  Sometimes, performance measurement is focused on the "outputs" -- number of permits issued, number of purchase orders processed, number of potholes filled -- and not the larger goals of permit streamlining, customer satisfaction, or pavement quality.  The strategic plan might be a great starting place for determining which measures will capture the interest of management, elected officials and the public.
Among the strategies that have worked for some Center for Performance Measurement participants are to set regular meetings with departments to consider how they're performing, and to consider performance data in the before/after discussions of any budget cuts or additions.  This helps to show where rosy expectations from a proposed action may not have panned out, or where there may be unintended consequences as well.
From the public's perspective, you might also want to consider what their patience is with the detailed data being collected.  Where you can summarize the findings to a few key points and tell them what it means, they're more likely to engage in the discussion.  On library services for example, knowing about changes in hours, materials acquisition expenditures, and wait-time for new releases may tell many patrons what they want to know, even though you may track much more than that internally (and have the data ready for when the discussion gets more specific).
Another great step is to find that one champion who "gets it."  That may be a department head, budget analyst, or just someone pushing for their own pet project.  Support them in making their case with data, and others will take their lead.
Jurisdictions that have done well at managing their performance programs are linked at the bottom of the CPM Certificate page:  http://icma.org/en/results/center_for_performance_measurement/services_and_publications/certificate_program.

answers.author: Gretchen Maynard
answers.text:
Any major change initiative is going to have detractors -- that just comes with the territory -- people generally aren't comfortable with change. So, my first suggestion is to recognize that. The second suggestion is to get clear on whether this initiative is still a priority within your organization. If it is, then my third suggestion is to ask for assistance -- start with a communication strategy. With so much economic uncertainty, many (if not all) leaders are very focused on day-to-day issues. So, gain clarity of purpose, understand this job is challenging and, ask for assistance from your colleagues -- to do this requires disclosure on your part.

answers.author: John Duffy
answers.text:
Another idea would be to compare and contrast your metrics with other jurisdictions.  Attempt to find out why your jurisdiction differs, especially for cases where you excel and where you do not.  You now can report to senior management and the rank and file employees where the organization is "better than average" and where it is not and most importantly why there is a difference so that superior performance may be celebrated/acknowledged  and how poor performance might be made better.  Good luck.

answers.author: Ken Masuda
answers.text:
I had a similar thing happen to me a number of years ago.  I was working in the CEO's Office when a new CEO was hired.  This person, CEO X, had no interest in performance management.  Unfortunately, about the same time, the elected Board member who was championing performance measurement/management had to retire for health reasons.  
We had to wait 5 years, until CEO X was gone and CEO Y, an ICMA member, was hired, to restart a new and expanded performance management initiative.  
As you say, the concept and practices have not yet become "ingrained" in the organization.   What are your options?  While I do not know your position or the size of your organization, I would ask:  Is there a department led by someone who has embraced the concept?  A place where a smaller, not organization-wide, "center of excellence" can thrive?
Feel free to continue this conversation by contacting me at: longwayhome23@aol.com

author: [Anonymous]
text:
I have been working for several years now on my localities' performance measurement/management initiative.  It's been very methodically done – with lots of staff support from within the organization.  The issue now is leadership (elected, top staff leadership)  and the lack of support and frankly, accountability.  I am not being held accountable for the work I am doing citywide, and certainly not department heads.  
We are still in the very infant stages of our initiative and have a ways to go but without this just basic support, encouragement and challenge, I feel like I am beating my head against the wall and doing it only for me.   And, staff that have been behind me are starting to fall off (they have not said this to me, but discussions around “credibility” have started coming up…..).  The organization was different when this initiative started, too.  Things change……and I wish we had been farther along when the change occurred, but that has not been the case.
What advice do others have who have found themselves in this same situation?
title: What to do when there's no support or encourage to do performance measurement?
